conflictDescription: Both user stories want to force patients to wear sensors continuously without exceptions, which is the same operation on the same event. There is no opposite instruction to start or stop the operation, so no conflict exists.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to make patients wear sensors without asking, so I get full health data quickly.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want to force users to wear sensors all the time without exceptions to collect all data needed for care.
generalResolutionType: 2. Update one and keep one remain the same
resolutionDescription: Update the caregiver story to allow ALFRED to encourage sensor wear with reminders rather than forcing, while keeping the developer story to enforce continuous sensor wear for data collection.
newUserStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to encourage patients to wear sensors regularly, so I get accurate health data.
newUserStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want to force users to wear sensors all the time without exceptions to collect all data needed for care.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires ALFRED to automatically log all clinical actions strictly, while User Story B forces all meetings to be online only, which may forbid or prevent logging actions during offline or in-person meetings. These impose opposite system behaviors on how meetings and logging operate under the same communication cluster.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to automatically and strictly log all my clinical actions to keep precise records without extra effort.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to force all meetings to be online, so that communication stays consistent and remote.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires automatic and strict logging of all clinical actions without extra effort, while User Story B wants to enforce online meetings when required, which may conflict if logging cannot occur during forced online meetings or if the system prioritizes meeting enforcement over logging. These impose opposite instructions on system behavior for communication events.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to automatically and strictly log all my clinical actions to keep precise records without extra effort.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to enforce online meetings when required, so communication remains consistent and remote.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires ALFRED to automatically and strictly log all clinical actions, while User Story B wants ALFRED to enforce formal commands only in other contexts, which may forbid or block some automatic or informal logging actions. These opposing instructions on system behavior when actions occur cause a conflict.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to automatically and strictly log all my clinical actions to keep precise records without extra effort.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to force formal commands for clear and professional communication in other contexts.

conflictDescription: User Story B requires all meetings to be forced online, while User Story A implies a preference for clear and professional communication that may include in-person or other styles. This creates opposing instructions about the mode of communication during meetings.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want to communicate clearly and professionally with patients to save time and avoid distractions during my shifts.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to force all meetings to be online, so that communication stays consistent and remote.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants clear and professional communication which may include flexible methods, while User Story B wants ALFRED to force online meetings, which may forbid other communication methods. These impose opposite instructions for communication style and method.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want to communicate clearly and professionally with patients to save time and avoid distractions during my shifts.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to enforce online meetings when required, so communication remains consistent and remote.

conflictDescription: Both user stories want to force users to wear sensors continuously, but there is no opposite or forbidding operation stated. They have the same goal, so no conflict exists.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to force patients to wear sensors and send data automatically, so I get full health information without delays.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want to force users to wear sensors all the time without exceptions to collect all data needed for care.

conflictDescription: Both user stories want to force patients/users to wear sensors continuously without exceptions, which means the system must enforce the operation. There is no opposing instruction to not do this, so no conflict exists. Therefore, these two user stories do not contradict each other.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver I want ALFRED to force patients to wear sensors and upload data automatically, so I get full health information without delay.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want to force users to wear sensors all the time without exceptions to collect all data needed for care.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to force patients to wear sensors and send data automatically, while User Story B wants to force users to wear sensors all the time without exceptions. The difference in 'patients' and 'users' and the strictness of 'all the time without exceptions' may cause conflict if some users are not patients or need exceptions. However, since both want to force wearing sensors, there is no opposite instruction, so no conflict exists.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to force patients to wear sensors and send health data automatically, so I get full and fast clinical information.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want to force users to wear sensors all the time without exceptions to collect all data needed for care.

conflictDescription: Both user stories want to force users to wear sensors continuously and upload data automatically, so they do not contradict each other. There is no opposite instruction or forbidding of an operation, so no conflict exists.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to force patients to wear sensors and upload health data automatically so I get full clinical information without waiting.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want to force users to wear sensors all the time without exceptions to collect all data needed for care.

conflictDescription: Both user stories want to force users to wear sensors continuously, which is the same operation. However, neither forbids the operation, so there is no opposite expectation. Therefore, there is no conflict.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to force patients to wear sensors and upload health data automatically, so I get complete clinical information without delays.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want to force users to wear sensors all the time without exceptions to collect all data needed for care.
